review.title: Nonparametric Bayesian Storyline Detection from Microtexts
review.abstract: News events and social media are composed of evolving storylines, which capture public attention for a limited period of time. Identifying these storylines would enable many high-impact applications, such as tracking public interest and opinion in ongoing crisis events. However, this requires integrating temporal and linguistic information, and prior work takes a largely heuristic approach. We present a novel online non-parametric Bayesian framework for storyline detection, using the distance-dependent Chinese Restaurant Process (dd-CRP). To ensure efficient linear-time inference, we employ a fixed-lag Gibbs sampling procedure, which is novel for the dd-CRP. We evaluate our baseline and proposed models on the TREC Twitter Timeline Generation task and show strong results.

metadata.title: Nonparametric Bayesian Storyline Detection from Microtexts

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: A long-term goal of collecting and gathering information is to identify and group text references to current events in the world (Allan, 2002), a task that would have applications in personalized news portals (Gabrilovich et al., 2004), intelligence analysis, disaster relief (Lotan et al., 2010), and understanding the characteristics of the news cycle (Leskovec et al., 2009). This task takes on new significance in the age of social media, where citizen journalists can document events as they unfold (Lotan et al., 2011), but where repetition and unreliable information challenge the task of the reader in particular (Becker et al., 2011; Petrovic et al al al., 2010). A major technical challenge is to mix information from two heterogeneous data sources: textual content and time.

sections.heading: 2 Model
sections.text: The basic task we are dealing with is to divide short text documents into an unknown number of storylines based on their textual content and their temporal signature. Textual content can be extremely sparse - the typical tweet is therefore in the order of ten words long - so the use of temporal information is crucial. In addition, the temporal signal is multi-scalable: in the 24-hour news cycle, some storylines will last less than an hour, while others, such as the disappearance of the Malaysian Airlines 370 plane in 2014, will continue for weeks or months. In some cases, the temporal distribution of references to a storyline will be unimmodal and well described by a parametric model (Marcus et al., 2011). In other cases, it may be irregular, with phases of activity followed by silence (He et al., 2007). Finally, it will be crucial to produce an implementation that has a scale to large companies.

sections.heading: 3.1 Online inference
sections.text: While we strive to speed up the calculation of individual Gibbs samples, the complexity of the basic algorithm in the number of instances is superlinear, because for each sample, the probability of instance i joining any possible cluster must be calculated, while the number of clusters itself grows with the number of instances (this growth is logarithmic in the Chinese restaurant process).Scalability to the streaming setting therefore requires more aggressive optimizations. To return to linear time complexity, we use a fixed-delay method (Doucet et et et et al., 2000).Once we have instance i, we perform Gibbs samples only within the specified window [ti − GA, ti] with cj < ti − GA remaining fixed. This approximate sampling method implicitly alters the underlying model, because there is no way to link i with a later message to absolute Cluj samples, where we are only interested in determining Gibbs > the temperature.

sections.heading: 3.2 Hyperparameter estimation
sections.text: The model has three parameters to estimate: • α, the concentration parameter of the dd-CRP • a, the offset of the distance function • η, the scale of the symmetrical dirichlet priority. In a procedure inspired by the Monte Carlo Expectation Maximization (Wei and Tanner, 1990), we combine maximization-based updates of these parameters with samples. Specifically, we calculate gradients with respect to the probability P (c) with respect to α and a, and perform gradient steps according to each specified number of samples. For the symmetrical dirichlet parameter η, we use the heuristics from Minka (2012) by setting the parameter to η = (K − 1) / 2 хk log pk, where K is the number of words that occur exactly once, and pk the probability of selecting the kest word from the vocabulary under the universal distribution for the entire corpus.

sections.heading: 4 TREC Evaluation
sections.text: To test the effectiveness of this approach, we evaluate on the Twitter Timeline Generation (TTG) task in the microblog track of TREC 2014. It involves tweeting based on a query Q to time T and returninga summary that captures relevant information. We perform the task on 55 queries with different timestamps and compare our results with 13 groups representing 50 runs for this task in 2014.We consider the following systems: Baseline We replace the distance-dependent previous with a standard funnel before. The number of clusters is heuristically set to 20. Annealed Gibbs sampling is used for inferencing. Offline inference The dd-CRP model with offline inference method (described in § 3).Online CRP model with online inference using online inference method (described in § 3.1).For the online inference implementation we set the size of the window and the number of iterations to five days and 500.

sections.heading: 5 Related work
sections.text: Space does not allow a complete analysis of the work involved, but see (Allan, 2002) for a summary of the "first generation" research. Recent non-Bayesian approaches focus on the overlap of strings (Suen et al., 2013), submodular optimization (Shahaf et al., 2012), and locality-sensitive hashing (Petrovic è et al., 2010). In Bayesian storyline analysis, the basic models are Topics-OverTime (Wang and McCallum, 2006), which link parametric distribution over time to each topic (Ihler et al., 2006), and the dynamic Topic Model (Lead and Lafferty, 2006), which treats evolution as a linear dynamic system (Nallapati et al., 2007).

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We present a simple non-parametric model for clustering short documents (such as tweets) into storylines that are conceptually coherent and time-focused. Future work could consider learning more flexible temporal distance functions that can potentially represent a temporal periodicity or parametric models of content popularity. Thank you to the reviewers for their helpful feedback. Later work by Diao et al. (2012) offers a model for identifying “bursty” topics, with inference requiring dynamic programming. All these approaches require the number of topics to be identified in advance. Kim and Oh (2011) apply a distance-dependent Chinese Restaurant Franchise for temporal topic modeling; they evaluate using predictive likelihood rather than comparing against ground truth, and do not consider online inference.

metadata.abstractText: News events and social media are composed of evolving storylines, which capture public attention for a limited period of time. Identifying storylines requires integrating temporal and linguistic information, and prior work takes a largely heuristic approach. We present a novel online non-parametric Bayesian framework for storyline detection, using the distance-dependent Chinese Restaurant Process (dd-CRP). To ensure efficient linear-time inference, we employ a fixed-lag Gibbs sampling procedure, which is novel for the dd-CRP. We evaluate on the TREC Twitter Timeline Generation (TTG), obtaining encouraging results: despite using a weak baseline retrieval model, the dd-CRP story clustering method is competitive with the best entries in the 2014 TTG task.
